vendor.name: 1Password
vendor.security_team: Emphasizes strong encryption and a human-centric approach to security.

category.reasoning: The user is asking about '1Password', which is a well-known password management software. The search results confirm that 1Password is used for saving and filling logins, credit card information, and other sensitive data, aligning perfectly with the 'Password Manager' subcategory under the 'Security' category.

critical.description: An issue was discovered in AgileBits 1Password, involving the method various 1Password apps and integrations used to create connections to the 1Password service. In specific circumstances, this issue allowed a malicious server to convince a 1Password app or integration it is communicating with the 1Password service.

Heap buffer overflow vulnerability in 1Password 8 for Mac, Windows, and Linux versions prior to 8.10.15, inherited from Google Chrome's libwebp component. This could allow an attacker to achieve remote code execution or steal secrets.

cve.summary: Vulnerabilities related to 1Password have been identified, with notable issues including CVE-2022-32550, which allowed a malicious server to impersonate the 1Password service. Another significant vulnerability, CVE-2023-4863 (also known as CVE-2023-5129), stemmed from the use of a vulnerable libwebp library, potentially leading to heap buffer overflows when displaying WebP images. This issue was inherited from Google Chrome components used in 1Password 8 for desktop. While the number of disclosed CVEs appears low in recent years, the nature of these vulnerabilities, particularly those inherited from third-party components, highlights the importance of timely patching and supply chain security.

certs.summary: 1Password is SOC 2 type 2 certified, ensuring secure data management for customer interests and privacy.
Confirms 1Password meets international standards for information security management systems.
Provides security controls and guidance for cloud environments.
Focuses on protecting Personally Identifiable Information (PII) in public cloud environments.
Specifies requirements for a Privacy Information Management System (PIMS).

compliance.overall_summary: 1Password holds multiple high-level compliance certifications, including SOC 2 Type 2 and a comprehensive suite of ISO certifications (27001, 27017, 27018, and 27701). These validations demonstrate a strong commitment to information security, data privacy, and cloud security best practices, meeting rigorous international standards. They also highlight 1Password's organizational maturity in managing and protecting sensitive information.

items.title: Phishing Campaign Targeting 1Password Users
items.description: Scammers sent convincing phishing emails impersonating 1Password's Watchtower feature, attempting to trick users into resetting their master passwords and revealing their secret keys. The emails directed users to fake websites designed to steal credentials.

items.title: 1Password Impacted by Okta Support System Breach
items.description: 1Password confirmed it was affected by a breach of Okta's customer support system, which led to an intrusion into 1Password's Okta environment. However, 1Password stated that no user data was accessed and the activity was terminated before any compromise occurred.

items.title: Mother of All Breaches (MOAB) and Microsoft Email Breach
items.description: These large-scale incidents highlight the risks associated with password reuse. The MOAB exposed billions of records, and the Microsoft breach involved state-backed hackers using password spraying. 1Password emphasized the importance of unique passwords and MFA.

items.title: Large-Scale Credential Leak (16 Billion Records)
items.description: Researchers discovered datasets containing approximately 16 billion login credentials, likely a repackaging of older breaches. 1Password advised users to check their accounts via Watchtower and practice good password hygiene to mitigate risks.

items.title: Phishing Campaign for Master Password Reset
items.description: A phishing campaign targeted 1Password users with emails falsely claiming their account password was compromised and requiring an immediate reset. The emails aimed to trick users into revealing their master password and secret key. 1Password confirmed this was not a breach of their systems.

incidents.summary: 1Password has been the target of several phishing campaigns and was indirectly affected by a breach at Okta. While no user data has been confirmed as accessed in these incidents, they highlight the ongoing risks of credential theft and the importance of robust security practices.

docs.summary: 1Password uses end-to-end encryption (AES-GCM-256) for data at rest and in transit, secured by account passwords and Secret Keys derived with PBKDF2-HMAC-SHA256. Authentication uses SRP to prevent password interception. Supports flexible unlock methods like biometrics. Data residency, retention, and audit logs are not detailed. Deployment is SaaS.
